name: vim
subtitle: Vim
about: Vim is a highly configurable text editor built to enable efficient text editing. It is an improved version of the vi editor distributed with most UNIX systems.

videos.title: Show invisibles
videos.description: In this episode, I demonstrate how to customise the appearance of these characters by tweaking the listchars setting. I go on to show how to make these invisible characters blend in with your colortheme.

videos.title: Tabs and spaces
videos.description: This episode explains the purpose of tabstop, softtabstop, shiftwidth and expandtab settings, and illustrates how Vim behaves using various combinations of these.

videos.title: Whitespace preferences and filetypes
videos.description: Different file types may require particular whitespace settings. These preferences can be specified by hooking into the FileType event with an autocommand.

videos.title: Tidying whitespaces
videos.description: This episode demonstrates a few techniques for tidying up whitespace. First, it looks at how to convert between tabs and spaces. Then it shows how to strip trailing whitespace, and finally, how to remove blank lines from a file.

videos.title: Indentation commands
videos.description: This episode covers the commands for shifting text left and right (< and >), and also goes over the auto indent command (=).

videos.title: Working with buffers
videos.description: Introducing the buffer list, and commands for switching between buffers. This episode also covers the concept of ‘hidden’ buffers, and shows how to deal with them.

videos.title: Working with windows
videos.description: This episode demonstrates all the essentials of working with windows: opening, closing, resizing, moving between and rearranging them.

videos.title: Working with tabs
videos.description: This episode covers the essential commands for working with Vim’s tab pages: opening and closing, switching, and moving them.

videos.title: Meet UltiSnips
videos.description: Snippets allow you to quickly insert predefined chunks of text into your document. The feature as I know it was first introduced in TextMate, but it has since been emulated by many other editors. For Vim users who want this functionality, the UltiSnips plugin is a great choice. Let’s start by looking at the basics.

videos.title: Operating on search matches using gn
videos.description: The gn command (introduced in Vim 7.4) makes it easy to operate on regions of text that match the current search pattern. It’s especially useful when used with a regex that matches text regions of variable length.

videos.title: Using Vim's paste mode with the system paste command
videos.description: When Vim is compiled without the +clipboard feature, we can still insert text from the clipboard using the system paste command (ctrl-v or cmd-v). This can produce strange effects, but we can avoid them by toggling the paste option each time we use the system paste command.

videos.title: Search multiple files with :vimgrep
videos.description: vimgrep is Vim’s built-in command for searching across multiple files. It’s not so fast as external tools like ack and git-grep, but it has its uses. vimgrep uses Vim’s built-in regex engine, so you can reuse the patterns that work with Vim’s standard search command.

videos.title: Profiling Vimscript performance
videos.description: Vim users are unforgiving of plugins that impair performance. Luckily, Vim provides built-in profiling tools that make it easy to diagnose performance issues. We’ll start by looking at how to profile the vimrc file, then move on to a real world scenario where profiling helped to identify and aleviate a performance bottleneck.
